page.title: 09FLORA IN THE PRESTON AREA
page.content: There are many woods scattered over the whole area.In addition to the natural woodland a considerable amount of tree planting was carried out in the 1880's to provide timber for fire_ wood and fencing.As well as adding to the natural beauty of the locality it is invaluable today for providing good cover for game birds,mainly pheasant, which are specially bred in captivity for the shooting season.The trees are a variety of deciduous and conifer and include oak,ash,sycamore,maple,hazel, hawthorn,holly,Norway spruce,larch and Scots pine.Ground cover is varied and consists of a wide range of wild plants and flowers.Large swathes of bluebells and bracken thrive in the dense woodland and a few wild orchids survive where crop spraying is not practised.
